data.title: Learn Dari With Me: My Resources and Apps
data.meta_description: Come learn Dari, the language of Afghanistan, with me. My favorite apps, resources, and timeline for learning this Persian language.
data.text:
When I booked my first trip to Afghanistan in 2024, I decided to try learning some Dari language in the 15 weeks before my trip. To learn Dari, I‚Äôve found, you need some tools. Frankly, there‚Äôs not a lot of information on how to learn Dari out there on the internet. It‚Äôs a pretty tough language without many resources.

As far as I can tell, you can‚Äôt walk into a library or bookstore and find Dari language books, unlike bigger languages like Spanish, French, or Arabic.

So I knew I‚Äôd need some tools on my journey. I was already casually learning Spanish (no real time set aside for it), so I was familiar with the popular apps for language learning, like Duolingo. Unfortunately, Duolingo does not offer Dari courses. Which is surprising, with some of the languages they do offer.

Anyway, Duolingo is great, but it has its flaws. For me, with my 300+ day Spanish streak, I find myself breezing through lessons and treating them as a chore. Yes, I‚Äôm learning a bit. But Duolingo serves as a fun reminder to practice Spanish, not my primary source of education.

So I wasn‚Äôt too bummed that Dari isn‚Äôt available on Duolingo.

The Languages of Afghanistan

Afghanistan is home to people who speak many different languages. There are multiple prominent ethnicities there, too. Tajiks, Hazaras, Pashtuns, and Uzbeks are names I‚Äôve come across while reading books about Afghanistan (I read some great books to prepare for my unfortunately cancelled trip).

A quick Google search tells me there are over 40 languages in Afghanistan, but two are primary: Dari Persian (or Farsi) and Pashto. When I decided to learn the language of this mountainous land, I wasn‚Äôt sure which language was most appropriate.

Asking around (to my tutor and Against the Compass guides), here‚Äôs what I learned about Afghanistan‚Äôs major languages‚Ä¶

Dari vs. Farsi

Dari and Farsi are two names for the same Persian language, which is prominent in Iran and Afghanistan. In fact, the Farsi (or Dari as many Afghans call it) spoken in the two separate countries is the same, only accents and some vocabulary are different. I‚Äôm no expert, but perhaps it‚Äôs something similar to British English and American English. I found in some of the books about Afghanistan I‚Äôve read, the term Farsi was used often, and many Afghans continue to call their official language this historically Persian word.

The writing systems of Farsi and Dari are much closer together than the spoken languages, so reading and writing sees almost no difference. Writing is based on a more formal, literary representation of the language, while spoken Dari and Farsi (and their many dialects) tend to take on nuances unique to different cultures and regions.

Confirmed! Dari vs Farsi

According to my Dari tutor, the differences between Dari and Farsi are similar to American English versus British English. He‚Äôs a native Dari speaker who lives in Kandahar, Afghanistan. For me, this is reassuring. There are many more resources online for learning Farsi, and when I‚Äôm looking for something in Dari, I usually find more Farsi resources.

This article from 2017 paints a picture of some of the tensions and historical complexities around the different names for Dari/Farsi.

In my favorite language-learning app, italki, both Dari and Persian (Farsi) are offered. Clicking either one, you‚Äôll see some of the same teachers. As far as I can tell, they‚Äôre mostly interchangeable. Always look for a tutor who is familiar with the place you‚Äôre traveling to!

Pashto

Well, what about Pashto? Pashto is another prominent language of Afghanistan spoken by ethnic Pashtuns, who (as far as I can tell) mostly dwell in the southern and eastern regions of the country. When I was planning my trip, I was told (by my Afghan italki tutor and my ATC tour guide) that Dari was the safer language to learn. Pashto is an entirely different language than Dari or Farsi. I‚Äôd be in the northern areas of Afghanistan, and many Pashtun people also speak Dari, since it‚Äôs the official language of the country.

Maybe next time, Pashto.

Greater Khorasan

If you‚Äôre traveling to Greater Khorasan (a quick Google search can show you this region), you‚Äôll be in Farsi-speaking territory. Depending on where you are, you might come across Persian Farsi (Iran), Dari (Afghanistan), Hazaragi, Tajik, and more! These are all dialects of the same language.

Pashto speakers will live south of this region, in Afghanistan. Though Dari is widely spoken in larger cities, like Kandahar.

Should I learn Dari or Farsi?

Dari and Farsi are two dialects of the same language, so which one you learn will depend on your travel plans and cultural interests. It‚Äôs the difference in learning British English or American English. They‚Äôre mutually intelligible, meaning someone who speaks Afghan Dari can hold a conversation very well with another person speaking Persian Farsi.

I chose to learn Dari because of my interests in Afghanistan: the mountains, the history, and the culture. Herat, a city in western Afghanistan, was once known for it‚Äôs arts, poetry, and literature (though I imagine they speak a Farsi closer to Persian). If Iran is more fascinating to you, find a Persian Farsi tutor (on italki there‚Äôre plenty).

Even these two beautiful languages have internal dialects that differ. Across Afghanistan, even just from Herat to Kabul, you‚Äôll hear many dialects of Dari, according to my Kandahar-based Dari teacher.

As you progress in whichever dialect you choose, you‚Äôll find yourself learning more about the other dialects, too, especially if you have a good tutor.

A Bamyan sunset, by Farid Ershad

The Best Advice I‚Äôve Received

When I started studying with a Mexican Spanish teacher on italki, he told me a very worthwhile piece of advice: when you begin learning a language, you are like a baby. Babies learn languages by listening, speaking sounds, and lots more listening. He told me not to write, not to read. These slow you down, confuse you, and (most importantly), they do not give you an ear for the language.

What happens when you don‚Äôt have an ear for the language?

You can‚Äôt follow conversations. Or listen and respond. You can‚Äôt communicate when you don‚Äôt begin like a baby.

I‚Äôm a big reader, and I love writing. Writing helps me memorize things. I‚Äôve spend lots of time in my journey to learn Dari writing English phonetics (Dari words spelled in English letters) of Dari words.

But the most important thing you can do when learning a new language isn‚Äôt to read and write. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt read at all!‚Äù he told me.

His guidance is backed up by this Language Learning Roadmap by Dreaming in Spanish (a very useful document for determining where you‚Äôre starting with a language). This professional, trusted guide in the language-learning world doesn‚Äôt recommend reading until you have over 600 hours of language practice under your belt.

In short, listen to Dari as you‚Äôre learning it. Nay, listen to Dari to learn it.

To learn Dari and eventually progress to reading it, I won‚Äôt be focusing on its beautiful alphabet at all.

That‚Äôs a bit of relief, isn‚Äôt it?

Shrinks the language down to just the sounds and the meanings.

That‚Äôs how I‚Äôm being taught to learn Dari.

I‚Äôm going to break it down for you‚Ä¶

Free Resources to Learn Dari

Someone people like to keep things free. I get that. Don‚Äôt skip the rest of this article (because I think you‚Äôll want to try italki, but use these great free resources, too. There aren‚Äôt tons of Dari YouTube videos, and not a lot of free listening content. That‚Äôs a problem. But if you pair some active listening (which you may need to pay for) with these free resources, you‚Äôll be in good shape.

Georgetown University Dari Textbooks: now, the textbooks themselves aren‚Äôt free, but the listening lessons that accompany them are. Click here to check out the two levels (Elementary and Intermediate). Just click the ‚Äúmultimedia‚Äù links, select your chapter, and start listening. My Dari teacher uses these textbooks, I believe.

Defense Language Institute Course: I‚Äôll mention this one down below again, but my goodness this is a complete, free course. Click here to see all the associated resources.

Persian Grammar Sketch: yes, it‚Äôs Persian, not Dari, but it‚Äôs got ~80 pages of grammar concepts and explanations for anyone who‚Äôs been studying for a little while. Make sure you do plenty of listening, don‚Äôt get bogged down reading. Click here to check it out, or shoot me an email and I can send you the PDF.

Conversational Dari by Eugene H. Glassman: a 400 page book written in 1971 with 25 intensive lessons. Check it out here.

The Best Apps to Learn Dari

I‚Äôm using the word ‚Äúapps‚Äù because it‚Äôs most appropriate, but this list is comprised of resources I‚Äôm using to learn Dari. If needed, I‚Äôll update them throughout my journey‚Äìand hopefully it‚Äôs a long journey! I guess it all depends on how much I enjoy visiting Afghanistan (update: my trip was cancelled‚Äìbut I‚Äôm still learning Dari!). If I never ever ever want to go back, I may move on from Dari and perhaps focus on the Persian dialect (because of the deep literature and poetry in Persian culture). But Afghanistan is full of mountains, and I love mountains, so I think Dari and I are beginning a long walk together. We‚Äôll see.

Here is my Dari language stack, AKA everything I‚Äôm using to learn Dari‚Ä¶

1. italki

italki is a language learning site and app that boasts this tagline: Become fluent in any language.

And so far, I believe it.

italki is full of rock star tutors who want to help people learn languages. There must be hundreds of highly rated, professional tutors on this app & website! They have introduction videos, a bio & qualifications, and open inboxes where you can ask questions. You can even take some trial lessons with tutors, risk free.

I‚Äôve already spent hours on italki with my Dari tutor, Ahmad. He‚Äôs a teacher by trade and tutors students around the world in Dari, Pashto, Farsi, and English.

italki is easy to use and navigate, I really enjoy just browsing the app for new language teachers.

Learning Dari with italki

There are two huge benefits to using italki to learn Dari: affordability and accessibility. The app has a very clean user interface and performs very well. I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs the perfect tutoring app, and I wish I‚Äôd found it sooner. I‚Äôm quite sure I‚Äôll use it for more languages, too, not just Dari. Exploring the app is like walking through a brightly lit store of knowledge and treasures!

Affordability

Because Dari is a language that is spoken in Afghanistan, it doesn‚Äôt cost much money to learn it. The cost of living in Afghanistan is very low, so a little goes a long way. You‚Äôll notice on italki that Spanish and French teachers with similar credentials and experience (and reviews) charge much more than Dari teachers. My 60 minute Dari lessons are $10 per lesson, so $10 per hour. My sister‚Äôs French tutor, on the other hand, charges $33 per hour. If you spend 1,000 hours studying these languages, you‚Äôll spend $10,000 on Dari and $33,000 on French. Yikes!

Accessibility

Dari is a language without many online resources. If you‚Äôre a native English speaker, or European, Dari is likely an incredibly strange (and beautiful) language to you. It‚Äôs musical, it uses an Perso-Arabic alphabet script, and much of the translations are not obvious. There are many underlying religious themes to basic phrases (like Salaam Alaykum and khoda hafez, or hello and goodbye). Indeed, many of the early phrases I‚Äôve learned in Dari for greeting are not as simple as hello and how are you?

I‚Äôm convinced you need a teacher to learn Dari (or Farsi). With italki, you‚Äôll find many teachers with thousands of ratings and reviews. Their profiles even list how many students they‚Äôve worked with.

Finally, italki knows how to find you the perfect tutor or teacher. When finding a teacher, you can select preferences for your teacher‚Äôs‚Ä¶

Native language

Where they‚Äôre from (amazing if you‚Äôre traveling somewhere specific)

Other languages spoken

Price range

So if you‚Äôre traveling to Afghanistan, you‚Äôd look for Dari tutors from Afghanistan! Perhaps you‚Äôd also want them to speak Pashto, or Arabic. You‚Äôre able to make those preferences. With their photos and introduction videos displayed, you‚Äôre also able to sort of interview teachers before messaging them. Oh! Yes, you can also message them to introduce yourself and ask questions. I message a few teachers before selecting one, no matter which language I‚Äôm exploring.

I‚Äôm a big italki fan.

My Favorite Feature

My favorite italki feature is choosing where you‚Äôre teacher is from. When I started taking Spanish more seriously, I found an instructor from my wife‚Äôs home state of Guanajuato in Mexico, where we‚Äôd traveled to. Plus, I got the authentic Mexican Spanish her family speaks.

2. Pimsleur

Pimsleur is an app that rejects memorization (no note-taking), instead focusing on pronunciation, repetition, and internalization. In other words, Pimsleur focuses on listening and speaking.

Well, don‚Äôt they all?

Not really.

Pimsleur teaches in 30 minute lessons. Each lesson is just listening to a short conversation, and responding aloud. Throughout the lessons, the native speakers teach you the sounds and nuances of the words (through their beginner-level conversation), while the narrator teaches you the meanings.

I have friends who use Pimsleur, and I do too, and it‚Äôs been recommended by my language teachers.

If you‚Äôve used an app like Duolingo (which does not offer Dari), you‚Äôll be pleasantly surprised at just how intentional another language learning app can be. No offense, Duolingo.

It‚Äôs pretty amazing that Pimsleur offers Dari amongst its 50+ languages. And while the Dari course isn‚Äôt as extensive as some others (looking at you, Spanish and Japanese), it‚Äôs been an amazing addition to my Dari language learning stack. I‚Äôve used it from the beginning, and it has walked very well alongside my https://pinetreepoet.com/italki-review/italki lessons.

When you‚Äôre learning with Pimsleur, go slow. Pause the lesson when necessary to think and respond. Don‚Äôt race the native speakers to respond, go slow and think, then respond, then listen. You get a lot out of the app this way. And don‚Äôt be afraid to repeat lessons, if necessary, as recommended by the app.

For anyone who wants to learn Dari, purchase a Pimsleur subscription. It‚Äôs well worth the cost for access to so much language learning potential, and such intentional direction, backed up by research.

If face-to-face tutoring with italki isn‚Äôt your cup of chai, Pimsleur is the next best thing. When you pair them together, you‚Äôll be amazing how fast you progress in learning Dari.

3. Podcasts to help learn Dari

Beyond italki and Pimsleur, I had to do some digging for more resources. After I was told to listen, listen often, and listen more when learning languages, I decided to try and find some resources to listen to. Frankly, there isn‚Äôt much out there for Dari. YouTube really only has this video, which isn‚Äôt very practical. It just shows you 200 phrases and how to pronounce them. I wouldn‚Äôt try to learn a language like that‚Ä¶

Afghan News

I listen to Afghan news to practice listening to the language. After only 10 hours of studying Dari, I was able to catch some familiar words! This is passive learning. I‚Äôm not sweating over every phrase, pausing and rewinding, and taking notes. None of those. On the advice of my italki Spanish tutor, I am just experiencing and hearing the language, like a baby!

I use a free news network (VOA Dari) to listen to native Dari speakers. You can check it out on Apple Podcasts here or YouTube here.

Voices of America (VOA Dari) is American government funded project to broadcast news in 45+ languages to over 350 million people around the world. Talk about propaganda! Only kidding, it seems to be a reliably neutral news network serving many different cultures.

I highly recommend this resource for listening to smooth, native Dari. Even though I can‚Äôt understand much of it, I get excited when I recognize a verb, number, or adjective!

Based on teachers I‚Äôve talked to, and my own experience, you really ought to listen to some native Dari, and this seems to be one good option out there. It‚Äôs slim pickings, though.

Chai and Conversation

Chai and Conversation is actually a Persian Farsi educational podcast and website (with a neat language course), not Dari. While I don‚Äôt pay for their premium website course, I like the podcast because I like learning about the culture of Persia, and it gives me some exposure to words used in Dari and Farsi. Plus, they talk a lot about poetry. Maybe that‚Äôs the reason I listen!.

Again, Chai and Conversation is not a Dari learning platform necessarily, but I enjoy the content and exposure to new words. I can always run the words by my italki Dari teacher if I have questions.

Listening to Chai and Conversation vocabulary lessons, I recognized most of the words from learning Dari. So it‚Äôs a good resource for expanding your vocab, and learning a thing or two.

4. Defense Language Institute Course

Whoa! That sounds serious, huh? Well, it‚Äôs a serious Dari course. For free, you can access the U.S. Defense Language Institute‚Äôs Dari course which, you can imagine, was used to train government employees and military members for their time in Afghanistan during America‚Äôs occupation.

I do not recommend too much time in this document. You can get really bogged down with the alphabet, and it‚Äôs not always relevant. However, I like to skim it here and there and see if I can pick up some new words.

Remember, listening is key! Don‚Äôt get stuck reading things slowly in your head with improper pronunciations.

But if you want to check out this comprehensive Dari language course, check out all the material right here.

5. Conversational Dari: An Introductory Course in Dari by Eugene H. Glassman

Alright, we‚Äôre reaching a bit here. This is a book published in 1971, and while physical copies are expensive, you can access a PDF file of it right here. The book is almost 400 pages (consisting of 25 intensive lessons), including vocabulary, pronunciation guides, and everything else you need to know about conversational Dari.

Is the book relevant?

As far as I can tell, it‚Äôs an excellent resource for learning Dari, though it doesn‚Äôt shy away from recommending certain exercises only be done with a teacher.

While the PDF of the book looks pretty outdated, it‚Äôs fun to look through and see things explained on paper. Sometimes, when working with Pimsleur and an italki tutor, you‚Äôll hear things and forget them. By browsing resources like Conversational Dari, you might recall and practice with things you‚Äôve heard.

I would definitely check out Glassman‚Äôs Dari course. If you‚Äôd like me to send you the PDF (I‚Äôve downloaded it), leave a comment at the bottom of this post. But you can access it easily with the link above.

6. An Introduction to Colloquial Kabul Persian

Even older than Glassman‚Äôs book, DLI published this guide in 1966 to teach conversational Dari, before it was even called Dari. But even the author recommends that ‚Äúthe best way to study these materials is with an Afghan informant from Kabul.‚Äù I like this book (and Glassman‚Äôs) because it provides context, common mistakes, and pronunciation guides based on American English. That‚Äôs helpful. Just like the two previous resources I listed, I recommend using this one sparingly and for fun.

Keep your attention on listening rather than traditional textbook or written material.

Nader Khan Hill, Kabul, by Qasim Mirzaie

Dari Language Stack

Alright, so how do we pile these apps and resources up to learn Dari? Well, to start, you should practice Dari every single day, just like if you were learning any other language. I practice Dari 5 days per week, with some combination of the following resources and tools. Nearly all of my daily practice is listening.

I built my routine based on the advice of my experienced italki tutors. Here‚Äôs my daily, weekly, monthly goals with learning Dari‚Ä¶

Passive vs Active Practice

Practicing a new language is of course an active practice, but there are lots of passive ways to learn, too. Active practice is intently listening, responding, and internalizing the new language. Here are some examples of active language practice with Dari‚Ä¶

italki tutoring

Pimsleur practice

Rehearsal by yourself, or with a friend

Homework assigned by your teacher (Ahmad, my teacher, gives me assignments after each class. They only take about 20 minutes.)

Passive language practice doesn‚Äôt require much work, just some time and curiosity. It‚Äôs listening! It could be podcasts or Netflix without subtitles. There‚Äôs no note-taking, rehearsal, or memorization. Passive learning is all about learning like a baby: just listening and absorbing.

I was told passive exercises water the flower of language learning. Without listening (and listening often), your flower will whither and die. Not my words, but an italki tutor. So far, my only passive exercise to learn Dari is the VOA Dari podcast, mentioned above. There just aren‚Äôt tons of Dari resources out there.

1. Daily Dari Practice

To start, I listen to 30-60 minutes of VOA Dari (the news podcast I mentioned above), 4-5 days per week. The newscasts are all exactly 30 minutes, so one or two of these each day is perfect. I listen to this newscast whether I have other lessons planned or not. While walking, commuting to work, riding a bike, or exercising you can make great strides in Dari without much mental energy expended. After just a few weeks of studying Dari, I recognized quite a few words on the podcast!

Secondly, I take Dari lessons on italki. Right now, I‚Äôm doing four tutoring sessions per week in addition to my VOA Dari podcast. italki tutoring has been huge for me. Speaking to someone from Afghanistan for an hour each day helps with pronunciation, the idioms and peculiarities of Dari, and understanding grammar. My tutor practices speaking and listening with me, gives me simple homework assignments that build over time, and offers consistent feedback.

italki tutoring is indispensable for learning a new language, especially one as unique as Dari or Farsi.

Finally, I use Pimsleur each day (or ~4 days per week, my ‚Äústudy days‚Äù). Pimsleur offers 30 minute intense language study sessions, all based on real, native conversation. I was surprised to find Dari on Pimsleur, so certainly take advantage of this resource.

Finally, I do some writing practice. Often this is assigned homework by my teacher, Ahmad. I internalize things very well when I write them, especially when I challenge myself with new vocab and grammar. So if your italki tutor gives homework, do it and do it well! We‚Äôre not learning the Dari alphabet yet, so this homework is written with the English alphabet‚Äìit‚Äôs a little strange to write words like khanom-e ma maqool ast, but remember you‚Äôve got to do plenty of listening to learn a language, not get bogged down with writing things you may not understand.

In summary, 4-5 days per week I listen to 1 or 2 episodes of VOA Dari, take a 60 minute italki lesson, do one Pimsleur unit, and complete my homework, or some casual sentence-writing to practice and internalize what I‚Äôve learned.

Here and there, too, I check out Farsi content (like the Chai and Conversation podcast) or one of the older, educational books I listed above.

2. Weekly Dari Practice

My goal for actively learning Dari is 8 hours per week. That‚Äôs 4 italki sessions (60 minutes each) and 4 Pimsleur units with practice exercises (30 minutes each), plus some time for homework and some writing practice. Additionally, I might browse the Defense Language Institute‚Äôs extensive Dari course.

But that‚Äôs all active learning.

On top of those 8 hours, I aim to get 3-7 hours of passive listening on VOA Dari. This isn‚Äôt much more than me getting excited when I recognize one in every hundred words.

Pro Tip

If you‚Äôre ever trying to figure out a word in Dari, but can‚Äôt, look up the Farsi word. There are way more Farsi/Persian resources online than Dari. Usually, the word will be correct, but you can always ask your tutor. Or ask me below in the comments and I‚Äôll find out for you during my next session!

3. Monthly Dari Practice (Goals)

Edit: after 3 months of learning Dari, I adjusted my goals to fit my schedule better. Tap here or scroll to Month 3 to see my more realistic language learning targets.

So how do these daily and weekly exercises stack up into monthly goals? Well, here‚Äôs about how much I want to practice Dari over the course of a month. Please note, I‚Äôve organized these from what I see as most essential to least essential.

16 hours of tutoring with a native speaker

8 hours of Pimsleur Dari units

15-30 hours of news in Dari via VOA Dari

6 hours of practicing, writing (in our alphabet, not Dari‚Äôs), and internalizing what I‚Äôve learned on italki and Pimsleur. Much of this is speaking aloud.

some casual research online, YouTube, and DFI‚Äôs Dari course. As curiosity strikes me.

1 hour of Chai and Conversation podcast, mostly just because I like it

Those are my monthly Dari goals! I‚Äôm about 15 weeks from my visit to Afghanistan (edit: it was cancelled üò≠‚Äìso I adjusted my learning goals after month 3), so I‚Äôm taking it pretty intensely. With all these added up, I expect to get about 30 hours per month of active Dari practice and lots of passive practice, which I don‚Äôt keep very close track of. That‚Äôs about 450 hours of solid practice before I leave!

My Progress Reports

I like documenting things, maybe that‚Äôs why I have a blog. So I‚Äôm laying out my progress below, for you and for me. If you want to learn Dari, I‚Äôd give at least five hours per week. Let‚Äôs see how I stack up compared to the goals I‚Äôve listed above‚Ä¶

Month 1 Learning Dari

Tuesday April 23rd through May 22nd, 2024

Active Practice: 16.5 hours italki (+30 minutes), 3 hours Pimselur (-5 hours), 7.75 hours practice & homework (+1 hour 45 minutes)

Passive Practice: 70 minutes Chai and Conversation (+10 minutes), 3 hours VOA Dari newscast (-12 hours)

Totals: 27 hours 15 minutes active learning (-2 hours 45 minutes) & 4 hours 10 minutes passive learning (-13 hours 50 minutes). That‚Äôs 56 minutes per day of active learning and 8 minutes 37 seconds per day of passive learning.

How did I do? Not bad! There‚Äôs room to increase my volume, for sure. Or perhaps I‚Äôll aim a bit lower. For italki and self-study, I hot my goals of 16 hours and 6-8 hours. While I need to increase my passive listening, I didn‚Äôt add the VOA Dari newscast until May 13th, after I learned how important these passive listening tools can be. Pimsleur I‚Äôd like to double my output in the coming months, aiming for 5-8 hours. It‚Äôs one of my favorite tools, after all.

Next month, I‚Äôll be visiting St. John in the USVI. I‚Äôd like to think I‚Äôll keep up my studies as intensely, but it‚Äôs likely it‚Äôll lag a bit.

Month 2 Learning Dari

Tuesday May 23rd through June 22nd, 2024

Active Practice: 4 hours italki (-12 hours), 3 hours 30 minutes Pimselur (-4 hours 30 minutes), 4 hours practice & homework (-2 hours)

Passive Practice: 12 minutes Chai and Conversation (-48 minutes), 3 hours 50 minutes VOA Dari newscast (-11 hours 10 minutes)

Totals: 11 hours 30 minutes active learning (-18 hours 30 minutes hours) & 4 hours 2 minutes passive learning. That‚Äôs 23 minutes per day of active learning and 8 minutes 3 seconds of passive learning.

My Afghan tutor and I both had week-long trips this month at separate times, so volume was super low on italki, which carried over into my other areas of study, too. He went to Bamyan and I visited St. John.

I think the cancelled Afghanistan trip slowed me down a bit, too, but I still planning on learning Dari Persian. Afghanistan and its Persian-speaking silk road neighbors and regions are still on my travel bucket list, for sure. Even my wife wants to visit Iran!

Anyway, took it pretty easy with language learning in general in this stretch, but I‚Äôll be back on it for month three of learning Dari.

My biggest takeaway from month 2 is that I enjoy learning Dari and meeting with Ahmad. While I‚Äôm still figuring out the scheduling of language learning (and this is my first serious foray into learning a new language), I‚Äôm enjoying the process and think I‚Äôll be a lifelong student of language.

Month 3 Learning Dari

Sunday June 23rd through Monday July 22nd, 2024

Active Practice: 9 hours italki (-5 hours), 90 minutes Pimselur (-6 hours 30 minutes), 4 hours 5 minutes practice & homework (-1 hour 55 minutes)

Passive Practice: 0 minutes Chai and Conversation (-60 minutes), 4 hours VOA Dari newscast (-11 hours)

Totals: 14 hours 35 minutes active learning (-15 hours 25 minutes hours) & 4 hours passive learning. That‚Äôs 30 minutes per day of active learning and 8 minutes of passive learning.

In three months (90 days) I‚Äôve spent 29 hours 30 minutes studying with a native Afghan tutor on italki, 8 hours learning on Pimselur, 15 hours 50 minutes practicing on my own. I‚Äôve also listened to 10 hours 50 minutes of news in Dari and 82 minutes of Chai and Conversation.

That‚Äôs an average of 35 minutes per day practicing and 8 minutes per day listening, or 65.5 hours in total.

I‚Äôve learned that with work and travel, this is an appropriate pace for me to learn Dari, so I‚Äôm adjusting my goals to resemble these numbers more. I was a bit ambitious in the beginning!

Here are my new monthly goals for learning Dari‚Ä¶

10 hours per month on italki

5 hours per month with Pimsleur (I definitely could‚Äôve done more Pimsleur in the last 3 months)
